Both models represent person/member data in healthcare contexts. Agent 1 (Person entity) includes comprehensive healthcare attributes like InsuranceProviderName, HealthcareProviderName, MaritalStatus, EmploymentStatus, EducationLevel. Agent 2 (Member entity) focuses on basic member information with InsuranceProvider and PrimaryCarePhysician. Common semantic elements include: demographics (DateOfBirth, Gender, Race, Ethnicity), contact information, and language preferences. However, Agent 1 has broader scope with employment, education, and emergency contacts while Agent 2 is more healthcare-member specific.

Significant structural differences exist. Agent 1 uses normalized design with separate ContactInfo and Language entities (lines 15-25) connected via one-to-one relationships. Agent 2 embeds contact info directly in Member entity (lines 4-7) and uses separate LanguagePreference entity (lines 12-16) with one-to-many relationship. Agent 1 has 3 entities with 2 relationships, Agent 2 has 2 entities with 1 relationship. Different primary key naming conventions: PersonID vs MemberID.
